endpage_p1: This is the end of experiment.
gherald_file_info_prior_bug: Among these changes, <1>{{priorBugs}}</1> bug has been found in this file.
gherald_file_info_prior_bug_plural: Among these changes, <1>{{priorBugs}}</1> bugs have been found in this file.
gherald_file_info_prior_change: FILE: This file has been modified in <1>1</1> prior change and <3>{{priorBugs}}</3> bug has been found.
gherald_file_info_prior_change_plural: FILE: This file has been modified in <1>{{priorChanges}}</1> prior changes.
gherald_line_info_prior_bugs: LINE {{lineNumber}}: the token <3>{{token}}</3> in this line were contained in <5>{{priorBugs}}</5> prior buggy lines.
gherald_line_info_prior_bugs_greater_tha: LINE {{lineNumber}}: the tokens <3>{{multiTokenText}}</3> in this line were contained in more than <5>10</5> prior buggy lines.
gherald_method_info_prior_bug: Among these changes, <1>{{priorBugs}}</1> bug has been found in this method.
gherald_method_info_prior_bug_plural: Among these changes, <1>{{priorBugs}}</1> bugs have been found in this method.
gherald_method_info_prior_change: METHOD: This method [<1>{{method}}</1>] has been modified in <3>1</3> prior change and <5>{{priorBugs}}</5> bug has been found.
gherald_method_info_prior_change_plural: METHOD: This method [<1>{{method}}</1>] has been modified in <3>{{priorChanges}}</3> prior changes.
gherald_report_file_risk_msg:
The file risk score is calculated by taking the average of the defective rate of each file. 
 The percentage is a relative score compared to the file risk score of the other changes.
gherald_report_method_risk_msg:
The method risk score is calculated by taking the average of the defective rate of each method. 
 The percentage is a relative score compared to the method risk score of the other changes.
home_about_content_p2:
In this experiment, we are going to ask you to complete two tasks that relate to code review.
 We will be using examples code commits taken from real-world systems and asking you to evaluate them in different ways.
home_about_content_p3:
The tasks will be timed.
 The timer can be paused if you get a phone call or want to grab a coffee.
 However, please do not pause the timer if you are actively working on the task.
home_about_content_p4:
We are aware that it may be possible for you to access the actual historic code reviews performed by the systems' original developers.
 We respectfully ask you <1>not</1> to do this, so that we can evaluate our research ideas without bias.
 However, you are free to use other tools or information sources that you normally use during code reviews.
home_about_content_p5:
You will have the opportunity to do a warm-up example for each task; see the <1>Start Practice</1> button below.
 These exercises will give you some familiarity with the task workflow, the UI, and the design of the experiment.
 The practise exercises will not be timed or evaluated by us.
home_about_content_p6: Once you are comfortable that you understand what you're being asked to do, you can begin the experiment by clicking on the <1>Start Experiment</1> button below.
home_practice_content_p1:
Before you start the real experiment, you'll be able to do a practice round of each task.
 This will give you some experience with the workflow of the task, the UI, and the problem space.
  We will not evaluate the results of the practice tasks, so take your time.
home_practice_content_p2:
Click on the <1>Start practice</1> button below to give it a try.
 Once you have completed the practice, the <3>Start experiment</3> button will be enabled and you'll be able to go on to the actual experiment.
home_practice_content_p3:
Note that while we are timing your responses, don't think of this as a race.
 Take the time you feel that you need to do the task to your satisfaction.
home_practice_content_p4:
Also, if you get a phone call or otherwise need to take a short break for some reason, please click on the <1>Pause</1> button.
 However, please do <3>not</3> pause if you're actively thinking about the task.
home_task_a_content:
In this task, you will be provided with three sets of code changes (i.e., proposed commits to an existing software system).
 Your job is to rank the changes from most to least risky, where we define risk as "the likelihood of a functional defect in the code that will need to be fixed later".
home_task_b_content:
In this task, you will be provided with the same three sets of changes that you saw in task A.
 Your job will be to identify all of the functional defects in the commit and log them (file name, line number, description of defect) in a report.
home_tool_gherald_content_p1: In this experiment, you will be provided with a tool called <1>Gherald</1> to assist your completion of tasks.
home_tool_gherald_content_p2:
In a nutshell, Gherald is a risk assessment technique we implemented based on historical analysis.
 During the tasks, you will be provided with Gherald risk assessment results regarding the riskiness of change and its relevant author, files, and methods.
home_tool_gherald_content_p3:
Specifically, you will be presented with an overall risk assessment in percentage/ratings regarding the author, files, and methods of the change.
 Moreover, Gherald will provide you the historical statistics of files and methods and alert you of the risky lines that are prone to defects when you are reviewing the code diff.
home_tool_gherald_content_p4: Please feel free to use Gherald as a complementary tool to help with your manual code reviews.
home_tool_gherald_content_p5: You can learn more details of Gherald by clicking on the <1>Tips for Gherald</1> button.
home_tool_infer_content_p1: In this experiment, you will be provided with a tool called <1>Infer</1> to assist your completion of tasks.
home_tool_infer_content_p2: Infer is a static analysis tool and it can detect bugs in terms of null pointer dereferences, memory leaks, coding conventions and unavailable APIâ€™s.
home_tool_infer_content_p3:
During the tasks, you will be able to see the output of Infer in the change detail page.
 Specifically, you will be presented with an Infer analysis report specifying the detected issues and the problematic line of code.
home_tool_infer_content_p4: Please feel free to use Infer as a complementary tool to help with your manual code reviews.
home_welcome: Welcome to our experiment on code review
questionnaire_allow_interview: I am happy to be contacted by the research team for a follow-up interview.
questionnaire_q1: How well do you think you understood the provided source code changes?
questionnaire_q2: How difficult did you find the assigned tasks?
questionnaire_q3: How would you describe your enthusiasm and energy level during the experiment?
questionnaire_q4: How useful did you find the information provided by the tool?
questionnaire_q5: What, if any, additional tools or information sources did you use during the experiment to help in your decision making?
questionnaire_q6: What, if any, problems did you encounter during the experiment?
questionnaire_q7: Do you have any additional comments or feedback on the tasks you performed and the information you were provided with?
task_a_content_p1:
You will be provided with three sets of code changes to an existing software system (i.e., proposed commits).
 Your job is to rank the changes from most to least risky, where we defined risk as "likelihood of a functional defect in the code that will need to be fixed later".
task_a_content_p2: To perform the ranking, just <1>drag and drop</1> the changes to the order you think is right. (1 = Most risky, 3 = Least risky).
task_a_content_p3: To start the task, click on the <1>I'm ready for Task A</1> button below.
task_a_content_p4:
Below are three sets of code changes to an existing software systems (i.e., proposed commits).
 Your task is to rearrange the ranking below by the amount of risk you perceive in the changes.
task_b_content_p1: In this task, you will be provided with the same three sets of changes that you saw in task A.
task_b_content_p2:
Taking each set one at a time, your job will be to identify as many defects in the commit as you can,
 and then log them in a code inspection form.
task_b_content_p3: Please focus on identifying <1>only</1> functional defects; please ignore any other flaws you might notice in the code, such as those relating to style or documentation.
task_b_content_p4: To start the task, click on the <1>I'm ready for Task B</1> button below.
tips_gherald_content_p1:
You are provided with a tool called <1>Gherald</1> to assist your completion of tasks. The Gherald risk assessment results are indicated by a <3 component={GheraldIcon} inheritViewBox/> icon.
 Please find the relevant icon during your completion of tasks.
tips_gherald_content_p2:
Gherald provides an overall risk assessment in percentage regarding the author, files, and methods of the change.
 <1>The risk percentage indicates the relative likelihood of introducing functional defects compared to the other authors/files/methods.</1>
tips_gherald_content_p3:
Gherald also provides an author-specific risk analysis that assesses the the author's project experience (i.e., how many changes the author has committed), recent activity (i.e., how many changes the author has recently committed), and file expertise (i.e., how many changes the author has committed to the files in change).
 <1>The rating indicates the relative value compared to the other authors. </1> 
 This information can be accessed when you <3>hover</3> over the info icon.
tips_gherald_content_p4:
Gherald provides a risk analysis for each file in change based on the historical statistics of changes and defects.
 <1>For each file being modified, an info alert will be displayed.</1>
tips_gherald_content_p5:
Gherald provides a risk analysis for each method in change based on the historical statistics of changes and defects.
 <1>For each method being modified, an info alert will be displayed above that method. </1>
tips_gherald_content_p6:
Gherald provides an line-level risk analysis based on the historical defect statistics of the tokens in each line of change.
 <1>For line containing tokens(function names) that have appeared in more than 10 prior buggy lines, a warning alert will be displayed below that risky line. </1>
 The warning alert indicates the risky tokens as well as their occurrence(in brackets) in prior buggy lines.
tips_practice_time_out:
Please note that the practice round is just for getting you familiar with the task workflow, the UI, and the problem space.
 Please do not spend too much time in conducting real code reviews and inspecting the code changes.
tips_task_a_content_p1: You can examine the details of each change by clicking on the <1>Learn more</1> button.
tips_task_a_content_p2: You can pause the experiment by clicking on the <1>Pause</1> button if you get a phone call or want to grab a coffee.
tips_task_a_content_p3: Once you are happy with your ranking, click on the <1>Submit</1> button.
tips_task_a_content_p4: If you feel unable to make a meaningful evaluation, you can click on the <1>Skip</1> button instead, and we'll advance you to the next one.
tips_task_b_content_p1: You can pause the experiment by clicking on the <1>Pause</1> button if you get a phone call or want to grab a coffee.
tips_task_b_content_p2: The source code can be accessed by clicking on the <1>Source code</1> button below. Feel free to download it if needed.
tips_task_b_content_p3: If no defect is found during the code review, you can click on the <1>No defect to report</1> button to proceed.
tips_task_b_content_p4:
If any defects are found during the code review, you can click on the <1>Report a defect</1> button to open up the code inspection form and log the defect information (file, line, comment).
 <3>If the defect is general and cannot be targeted to a specific line, feel free to leave it as blank and just put the comment. </3>
